text: When a BBC colleague reads out the Shipping Forecast & says a gale is imminent, their meaning is very precise: “within the next 6 hours”.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Civil war, beheaded king, gunpowder plot, fire of London, bubonic plague, Glencoe massacre, death of Shakespeare. Not sure the 1600s are great for precedents. (Apart, I suppose, from Pepys’s diaries, the King James Bible & Glorious Revolution)
author: BBCJLandale

text: But charities fear the debate has shifted. Aid critics no longer attacking the 0.7 target. They are now pushing to change how & by whom the £14bn is spent: OECD ODA rules relaxed or ignored, greater UK control, more focus on UK economic interests, less spend by multilaterals etc
author: BBCJLandale

text: also tells aid sector to "chill out" about fears UK promise to spend 0.7% of GNI on aid is under threat, claiming her predecessor @patel4witham & @the_tpa are not attacking the target: "We ought to be talking more about what 0.7 - & what all of you - are achieving"
author: BBCJLandale

text: International Development Secretary @PennyMordaunt tells #BondConf her department is not about to be merged with the #FCO: "There are no plans at all for @DFID_UK to be hoovered up by any government department or turned into something else."
author: BBCJLandale

text: Perhaps we should all follow the advice of Colonel Wintle in his unpublished letter to @thetimes:
author: BBCJLandale

text: This is an important story: proof - among other things- that Algeria cannot be governed from a hospital bed in Switzerland.
author: BBCJLandale

text: The only excitement greater is that which awaits a reader about to dive into the Patrick O'Brien novels for the first time.
author: BBCJLandale

text: The grace & grit of Nancy Astor in the face of an astonishing line of questioning that shows how far attitudes have changed.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Thank you, Chris, very kind.
author: BBCJLandale

text: What diplomatic protection means & what impact it may have on Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe
author: BBCJLandale

text: The UK has given “diplomatic protection” to Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe. This happens very rarely. The campaign group REDRESS reckons the last time the UK did this may have been in 1951 to protect an oil company in a commercial dispute with, yes, Iran.
author: BBCJLandale

text: BBC News - Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe: What will diplomatic protection mean for her? https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-47490695 …
author: BBCJLandale

text: Iranian ambassador to UK responds to @Jeremy_Hunt’s decision to give diplomatic protection to Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe
author: BBCJLandale

text: The question now is how Tehran will react - will it respond positively to the pressure or step up the confrontation?
author: BBCJLandale

text: What British diplomats hope is this sends a clear signal to Iran that this issue is not going away, that the UK is determined to keep pushing for Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe's release, & that it is prepared to escalate the dispute in the face of Tehran's intransigence.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Granting diplomatic protection is extremely rare. Not been used by the UK in living memory. It means the UK considers Iran's treatment of Mrs Zaghari-Ratcliffe - her lack of access to due process and medical treatment - has failed to meet international standards.
author: BBCJLandale

text: That potentially opens up the possibility of the UK taking legal action against Iran. But officials suggest this is unlikely. Instead, the UK will use this device to raise the case more easily in international forums like the UN.
author: BBCJLandale

text: "Diplomatic protection" is not like diplomatic immunity - that protects diplomats from prosecution. What this does is turn a consular case into a formal legal dispute between the UK & Iran.
author: BBCJLandale

text: The Foreign Secretary @Jeremy_Hunt has decided to grant formal diplomatic protection to Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, the British-Iranian dual national detained in Iran. A significant escalation in the UK's campaign to secure her release.
author: BBCJLandale

text: You are, of course, quite right & I stand corrected. There were, however, one or two old fashioned subs on The Times in 1992 who much disliked their reporters sneaking jokes into copy.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Chris, a long time ago I wrote a weekend shopping column for The Times, informing readers of the best supermarket deals for meat and fish. One intro began “Cod pieces are up this weekend...” The subs never spotted it & it lasted all editions.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Worth a read. It is rare in this debate for anyone to step back & lift their eyes to the broader horizon.
author: BBCJLandale

text: A long time ago I wrote a weekend shopping column for The Times, informing readers of the best supermarket deals for meat and fish. One intro began “Cod pieces are up this weekend...” The subs never spotted it & it lasted all editions.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Thanks so much for coming, Elizabeth, and for all your support  #TurnTheTables #CancerReliefUK
author: BBCJLandale

text: ⁦@Jeremy_Hunt⁩ in Yemen warns Stockholm peace process could be “dead within weeks” unless both sides in conflict live up to commitments to clear Hodeidah of militia
author: BBCJLandale

text: @Jeremy_Hunt visiting Yemen, 1st western foreign minister to do so since 2015.  Not sounding optimistic.
author: BBCJLandale

text: A fine obit for a dedicated public servant.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Significant if true. Not clear yet if President Rouhani has accepted. Zarif a key Western interlocutor & big player in JCPOA negotiations.
author: BBCJLandale

text: This obviously a matter of judgement. But Egypt insists Sharm airport security now OK & and some Whitehall insiders say ex-Home Secretary PM being overly cautious. Others worry that flight ban having real impact on UK-Egypt relations.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Re UK ban on flights to Sharm el-Sheikh, @theresa_may says security of UK nationals top priority: "We understand the importance of the issue to Egypt & while we have not yet concluded that it is right to lift the restriction on flights, we continue to keep that under review."
author: BBCJLandale

text: Should diplomacy, like charity, begin at home?
author: BBCJLandale

text: This ticks many boxes. Gives UK something to say when defending JCPOA.  Pleases US & Israeli allies who want more pressure on Iran. Allows Tories to highlight Labour leadership sympathy for anti-Israel groups. Allows ministers to look tough in leadership race.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Why the UK should remember Gladstone’s adage that the first principle of foreign policy should be “good government at home” https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-47241921 …
author: BBCJLandale

text: BBC News - How will the UK's post-Brexit global role look? https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-47241921 …
author: BBCJLandale

text: This, from the German minister for foreign affairs.
author: BBCJLandale

text: “If you were to say that Gordon will be prudent for a purpose, you won’t be too far wrong, but you didn’t get that from me, alright?” Almost seems like yesterday...
author: BBCJLandale

text:
Across the wet November night
The church is bright with candlelight
And waiting Evensong.
A single bell with plaintive strokes
Pleads louder than the stirring oaks
The leafless lanes along.
(Betjeman, of course...)
author: BBCJLandale

text: I don’t really understand this - something to do with football - but diplomatic banter clearly thriving between UK & German foreign ministries. #DespiteBrexit
author: BBCJLandale

text: Scraping jam mould is the perfect Brexit metaphor because it is so flexible. It could imply cherry picking the best bits of EU membership after we leave - or staying in the EU but reforming it to our taste. As ever, thrifty @theresa_may keeps us guessing...
author: BBCJLandale

text: UK to fund £6.5m aid package to Venezuela. Mainly nutrition, healthcare, clean water and sanitation. Sidestepping barriers by supporting humanitarian agencies already on the ground. DFID not naming NGOs to avoid reprisals.
author: BBCJLandale

text: It is even worse when taking a short hand note. In Brussels, I would often return from a briefing unable to decipher whether the characters in my notebook represented the original French or my English translation.
author: BBCJLandale

text: There is only one question, surely: which is Talleyrand, the great survivor?
author: BBCJLandale

text: Seaman, entrepreneur, spy, racer, mischief maker: Sir Robin Knox-Johnston 50 years after becoming the first man to sail solo around the globe without stopping
author: BBCJLandale

text: Thank you so much, Jesse, very kind.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Again, this is quite a thing, quite a statement from one EU member to another, knocks @eucopresident's "place in hell" remarks into a cocked hat.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Amid Brexit, other tensions emerge in Europe. Rare for relations between two EU founder members to deteriorate this much. Further evidence of European political consensus fracturing.
author: BBCJLandale

text: This reminded me of a teacher I once had who channeled Dorothy Parker each morning as he entered the class room, surveyed the scrofulous young charges before him and asked: "What fresh hell is this?"
author: BBCJLandale

text: I didn’t touch his porridge though...
author: BBCJLandale

text: Echoes of 1997, eh @Kevin_Maguire?
author: BBCJLandale

text:
End of an era. But what an era!

text: Well, Brady is a very good quarterback...

text: You will be glad to know that all diplomatic avenues were explored first before the military were brought in.
author: BBCJLandale

text: That awkward moment when the Secretaries General of NATO & the United Nations both turn up at the BBC Davos office at the same time. Who goes on air first? Diplomacy or military? The eternal question...
author: BBCJLandale

text: And I am a big fan of Giles!
author: BBCJLandale

text: A la recherche du temps perdu...
author: BBCJLandale

text: Foreign Office minister summons Zimbabwean ambassador to FCO to express "deep concern" about "disproportionate response" by security forces to unrest including the "use of live ammunition, intimidation and excessive force"
author: BBCJLandale

text: "The weight of their calling is too much to bear in their own strength..." An elegantly savage assessment of our parliamentarians by an archbishop who prays for them thrice daily #Bellman
author: BBCJLandale

text: After many years studying the political species, I have never understood the desire to address cameras flanked by colleagues. The doughnutters, so to speak, distract from what's being said, often look menacing & subtly suggest the speaker can't be allowed out by him/herself.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Sources say @Jeremy_Hunt will discuss lack of medical attention and lack of progress in the case of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe case
author: BBCJLandale

text: Medical, not medial. Apologies.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Breaking: UK Foreign Secretary @Jeremy_Hunt to summon Iranian ambassador to UK @baeidinejad to FCO to discuss Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe who begins 3 day hunger strike today in protest at being denied medial care in Tehran prison
author: BBCJLandale

text: Much political debate is coarse and shrill. But here is an exception. You do not have to agree with @nsoames to recognise an old-fashioned speech that makes an argument, moderately & elegantly, with just enough quiver of voice & lip to convey the deep passion that lies behind it
author: BBCJLandale

text: An octet of former King Charles St residents on Britain's post-Brexit foreign policy. And, unsurprisingly, they do not all agree.
author: BBCJLandale

text: The plus fours, surely?
author: BBCJLandale

Here is the full letter from @Jeremy_Hunt

text: Breaking: FCO says it will no longer make some victims of forced marriages take out loans to pay for flights home. Existing loans written off, passports returned. But FCO will still make most perpetrators pay repatriation costs via FMPOs.
author: BBCJLandale

text: The first pictures showing the arrest of Nazanin Zaghari Ratcliffe in April 2016, according to a documentary broadcast on Iranian state TV.
author: BBCJLandale

text: This is worth reading. So much Brexit coverage/analysis is micro noise. All too rarely do people step back from the fray and draw broader conclusions. And one does not have to agree with all of @CER_Grant's conclusions to note that he does this very deftly.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Iran’s foreign minister trolls @realDonaldTrump

text: My New Year wish for Twitter #2019: less anger, swearing, deceit & high dudgeon; more nuance, understanding, forgiveness & wit. #nildesperandum

text: Never let it be said the British have lost their sense of humour. I wonder how many of these replies the great @nytimes will publish.

text: Today at Westminster, the implicit became explicit: Tory divisions now have numbers attached & Theresa May’s premiership has a declared teleology. The key question is whether this changes in any way the politics of Brexit and paves the way for new thinking & new alliances.
author: BBCJLandale

text: Meanwhile, back in another solar system, there are positive noises emerging from Stockholm where the combatants in a dreadful, bloody war are contemplating alternatives to fighting.
author: BBCJLandale

text: I trust there was mention of lunch too?
author: BBCJLandale

text: Echoes of the late Lord Sutch of Monster Raving Loony fame: "Vote for Insanity: you know it makes sense."

text: Ouch! @jameskirkup giving voice to some vintage Brexit rage. I am not sure anyone quite escapes his ire.

text: The hope vested in these talks cannot be overstated, nor the importance to millions facing starvation underestimated
author: BBCJLandale

text: @NickBryantNY on GHW Bush: “‘He was the leading statesman of a united world.’ In a splintered nation and in a fractious world, it is hard to imagine those words every again being written of a contemporary American president.”
author: BBCJLandale

text: Ever wondered what ⁦@realDonaldTrump⁩’s motorcade looks like from above? Here it is keeping the good folk of Buenos Aires awake...

text: What a great opportunity for an ambitious young journalist! And what a bleak reminder of one’s age... Thank you @nicholaswatt & @SVaughanAuthor

text: A great loss of a parliamentary original. I once had the honour of hearing Lady T sing the Chattanooga Choo Choo. Acappella. It was unforgettable. (Key fact: she was a ‘land girl’ on Lloyd George’s farm before she worked at Bletchley)
author: BBCJLandale

text: When I met Sina in Tehran last week, he challenged my preconceptions about life in Iran
author: BBCJLandale

text: There is a lovely gag in ‘The Real Marigold Hotel’: “Everything will be alright in the end. So if it is not alright, it is not the end.”
author: BBCJLandale

text: Mark hi, thanks for your tweet. The BBC rarely gets the chance to report from Iran. Do you not think it legitimate journalism to ask Iranians how they are dealing with sanctions? I spent 3 days talking to as many folk as I could & got a variety of responses. That’s reporting.
author: BBCJLandale

text: An amazing opportunity to work on a fantastic newspaper.
author: BBCJLandale

text: What do Iranians think of US sanctions? I went to Tehran to find out.
author: BBCJLandale

text:
Will US sanctions on Iran work? I have had the rare chance to go to Tehran to ask people there what they think. 
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-middle-east-46310538/what-do-iranians-think-of-us-sanctions …
author: BBCJLandale
